entry.title: How to unlock Divalo in Anime Vanguards
entry.summary:
The Occult event in Anime Vanguards brings a host of new content in the popular Roblox title, and you can now unlock Divalo to add to your team.
The addition of every new character adds to the excitement, and Divalo will be a hot favorite of anyone who loves Jojo's Bizarre Adventure: Golden Wind. To play with him, you'll have to obtain the character first. Let's take a look at how you can obtain him in the first place and if you should spend your resources to do so.
How to obtain Divalo in Anime Vanguards
Certain characters in Anime Vanguards can be obtained by playing the game. Divalo, on the other hand, is exclusive to the Occult Banner. This banner can be summoned at the shop with the help of Spirit Wisps. The hardest part is the pull rate - the chances of obtaining Divalo from the banner is only 0.005%.
Screenshot by Destructoid
In case you need clarification about Spirit Wisps- they're a new type of currency that can be used to unlock the Occult Banner. You can obtain it by playing the new event mode or purchase it directly by spending real-life money. If you choose to go with the latter, expect to spend a lot of time finding this character. His being of Vanguard rarity makes things much harder, as his pull rate is really low.
While adding the latest banner character to your team is always exciting, Divalo might not be worth it. He isn't broken by any means based on his stats and abilities. Unless you're a beginner (in that case, you won't have enough resources), it's better to save your resources or try to get the Gujo (Secret unit).
If you manage to get him, the priority is to evolve him as soon as possible. The requirements remain unknown as I have yet to pack him, but going for evolution will improve his stats and in-game abilities. If you are unsure about who the best characters are, make sure to go through our Anime Vanguards tier list.

entry.title: Is There Night Vision in Stalker 2?
entry.summary:
As all fans know, the ability to toggle on night vision when equipped with certain items has been a vital part of the Stalker experience since the debut of its first title, as well as a godsend when exploring the darkest corners of The Zone.
Due to that, it was a given that the feature would return in Heart of Chornobyl, right? Here's whether or not you can access night vision in Stalker 2: Heart of Chornobyl.
Is There Night Vision in Stalker 2?
Unfortunately for all looking to go against the odds and explore during the nighttime, Stalker 2 does not allow players to activate night vision, as no weapons, armor pieces, or suits in the game seem to provide the feature, even through upgrades. Although we know that's disappointing, the way certain enemies within the game seem to have the goggles equipped might point out their inclusion during a post-launch patch.
The Best Alternatives for Night Vision in Stalker 2
Although the item won't be able to hold a candle to the effectiveness of the night vision goggles, using your helmet's flashlight will be your best bet when in the dark, as it will allow you to illuminate the immediate area ahead and at least know where you are going. You can turn your flashlight on and off in Stalker 2 on both PC and consoles by following the steps below. It's also important to point out that your flashlight runs on an infinite supply of batteries, so don't worry about overusing it.
PC (Mouse + Keyboard): By opening your Radial Menu with TAB and then pressing E.
Consoles (on when playing on a controller): By quickly pressing RB.
Now that you know the best alternatives for NV, don't forget to also check out the best early armor locations in Stalker 2 so that you can make sure you will be well-geared to face any threats in your quest to make it big.

entry.title: How to link your EA FC 25 Ultimate Team account with Twitch
entry.summary:
It's that time of the year once again, and you'll want to link your EA account with Twitch to earn some fantastic rewards in EA FC 25's Ultimate Team mode.
November will mark the beginning of the FC Pro Open, the first major esports tournament conducted by EA Sports. As viewers, you'll be able to earn seasonal XP and free rewards by simply watching the upcoming streams on Twitch. But first, you'll have to do the important task of linking your EA account with Twitch to ensure all the rewards.
EA FC 25: How to link your EA account with Twitch
For starters, you'll need a Twitch account, which is easy to create. Once done, complete the following steps to connect your EA account with Twitch.
Go to the Settings section in your EA account.
Choose Connections.
In this section, you'll find a list of all third-party accounts that can be connected with your EA account.
Select the Link button beside Twitch.
Enter the security code (only if you have an App Authenticator enabled).
Sign in to your Twitch account in the next step (opens automatically after you select Link).
Select Authorize, and then choose Link Accounts.
Image via EA
Once done, a pop-up will appear, confirming that the link has been established successfully. Your EA account will now become enabled for Twitch Drops, and you'll be eligible for all applicable rewards. The FC Pro Season 1 is just the tip of the iceberg, as you can expect similar objectives to arrive in the future as well.
Additionally, you'll also get a free Mega Pack in EA FC 25 once you've linked your EA account with Twitch. If you want to connect your EA account with YouTube, the process is precisely the same. If you haven't linked your accounts, make sure to do it before November 2 to complete the FC Pro Season 1 Objective with ease.

entry.title: How to unlock the Electric Field safe in Stalker 2
entry.summary:
The Electric Field safe is one of the many hidden chests you'll come across in Stalker 2: Heart of Chornobyl. However, it's perhaps one of the hardest safes to unlock if you have to determine the code on your own.
This particular chest can be found in Garbage, so you'll have to play a bit to gain access. While you can travel to the location at any given time, it's better to concentrate on the main campaign missions. Once you've reached Slag Heap, you can start trying to unlock the chest.
Stalker 2 Electric Field safe code
To reach the stash located in the safe, you can travel to the location marked on the map. The stash can be found upstairs, and you'll need a four-digit code to reach it in the first place. Type in the following code - 1708 on the keycode machine to reach the safe.
In case you're wondering about how I reached the solution, it's related to the description of the place. When you open the stash on your map, it has the following description.
Image via Destructoid
"It's a good hiding place. I'm surprised the electronics are still functional. Hopefully they still are... anyway, the code is stick, cobra, porthole, infinity."
The last four words, which appear as something completely random, are your clues. Each of them represents a numeric digit that looks like the words (not identical, but there will be a close resemblance).
Stick - 1
Cobra - 7
Porthole - 0
Infinity - 8
In that order, the code required to open the Electric Field safe is 1708. Sadly, this is one of those stashes you might just give a skip. After opening the stash, you'll get meds, ammo, food, and grenades. They're useful for sure, but not worth a separate hassle. If you're about to pass over the location as part of some question, make sure to give the location a visit to get the free loot.

entry.title: Helldivers 2 devs once considered a licensed cosmetic system that basically let you hallucinate a different world
entry.summary:
Helldivers 2 developers Arrowhead have been voluble lately about potentially adding elements from other sci-fi worlds to the shooter, with chief creative officer Johan Pilestedt rubbing his hands gleefully at the prospect of partnerships with Warhammer, Alien, the Fifth Element, and more besides. Speaking at the G-STAR Conference in Busan earlier this month, recently appointed chief executive officer Shams Jorjani confirmed that Arrowhead are looking into such collaborations, giving the example of refitting your dropship to look like one of Halo's Pelicans, or introducing the Zerg from Blizzard's Starcraft as an enemy faction. Jorjani cautioned listeners, however, that these injections of third-party DNA need to look and feel appropriate to the setting. After all, if you start fecklessly chucking the Zerg, Chaos Space Marines or Fifth Element's, er, flying taxis into Helldivers 2, it might spoil the meticulous coherency of a game in which saluting protects you against lethal falls and some guy called Joel is running the universe. The funny part is that according to Jorjani, Arrowhead once envisaged a system that would get round the problem of inconsistency by essentially making third-party cosmetics, including whole map skins, visible only to players who have them enabled. To put that another way, Arrowhead once envisaged a system in which individual Helldivers would hallucinate other licenses.

entry.title: Metal Slug Tactics review: the crunchy arcade run 'n' gun pauses to have a tactical think
entry.summary: I am a very casual enjoyer of Metal Slug games. I've never actually paid for one of these side-scrolling shoot 'em ups, except for all the countless coins I happily pumped into arcade machines as a child. To this day, if I see a rare glittering cabinet running one of these crunchy shmups, I will go ham for twenty or thirty minutes, and walk away satisfied that I have seen a lot of very good pixels. These games, I am convinced, were never really designed to be completed, but to be played exactly like this, as a coin-gobbling invitation to become a bandana-wearing sisyphus, a tiny Rambo pushing a bouncy, juddering tank up a hill occupied by cartoon nazis. You die a bunch and say: "ah, that was good." So what happens when you rearrange the molecules of this run and/or gun 'em up into an isometric turn-based strategy game? You get Metal Slug Tactics, an off-kilter nod to Into The Breach and other grid-based turn-takers, but secretly housing the aggressive notions of an unhinged pyromaniac. You still die a lot. And you still walk away feeling fairly happy about it. Read more

entry.title: Soulframe has the bones of a great action-RPG, but I’m enjoying it partly because it feels too late to enjoy Warframe
entry.summary:
I've been trying to work out if I'm keen on Soulframe only because I feel guilty about missing the boat with Warframe. I reviewed Digital Extremes' hit free-to-play shooter in 2013, back when people were still calling it a spiritual successor to the developer's boomerang-throwing action game Dark Sector. I didn't like Warframe much at the time. Think I gave it a 6/10. Warp forward a decade, and that 6/10 game has become a thriving live service phenomenon - fifteenth on the Steam Most Played charts at the time of writing, and profitable enough to spawn its own annual TennoCon expo. It's also become an intoxicating, confusing morass of dynastic sci-fantasy politicking and genre-shifting expansions, ranging from capital ship mechanics to questions of time travel, wrapped in layers of cosmetics that make Destiny look about as colourful as Gears Of War.
I definitely didn't see all that coming. I doubt Digital Extremes saw it coming either. Warframe today feels like a lab experiment run amok. I love its appetite for novelty, but there's a lot for a returning player to catch up on and, frankly, it feels like homework. As such, I had a couple of broad motivations for playing Soulframe's pre-alpha "prelude": I'm keen to see what Digital Extremes can do when they aren't encumbered by 10 years of world-building, and I want to get in on the ground floor before they absolutely swamp this thing in updates.

entry.title: Inside Snap Tap, the new hotness keyboard feature outlawed by Valve
entry.summary: The gaming keyboard market is currently tripping over itself, trying to equip everything with the technology most commonly known as Snap Tap: a feature that promises hyperfast inputs of two alternating keypresses, making you an unkillable side-strafing blur in your FPS of choice. Introduced on Razer’s Huntsman V3 Pro series and quickly followed by Wooting’s (functionally distinct but effectively identical) Rappy Snappy, Snap Tap is now wearing multiple names as it takes over the world of RGB peripherals, from SteelSeries’ Rapid Tap to Corsair’s FlashTap and Keychron’s... Last Keystroke Prioritisation. Which doesn’t sound as sexy, but still. However, Snap Tap is also drawing a level of ire that exceeds the usual baseline scepticism of hardware marketing. Because it enables a form of input automation – where you can quickly move in two directions by rapidly tapping one key, while holding down another – it’s considered by some as tantamount to cheating, allowing players to cross the line that divides unfair play from the accepted comforts that come with simply using a responsive Hall Effect keyboard or high-refresh-rate monitor. It’s even become a bannable offence in certain games, most notably in Counter-Strike 2. Neither side is backing down; in an astonishingly worded tweet, Wooting went as far as to concede Snap Tap "should be considered cheating. But if it’s allowed, you need it." But do you? Read more

entry.title: Rescue your twin from the clutches of the evil Castle Master
entry.summary: Castle Master, the haunting conclusion to the Freescape engine saga, is now ready for public testing! Prepare yourself for a perilous adventure as you lower the drawbridge to enter the Castle Master’s domain. Released in 1990 by Incentive Software, Castle Master became popular for its technical innovation and challenging gameplay. The game inspired countless 3D adventure titles, and the Freescape engine itself marked a technological milestone, enabling groundbreaking object interaction and spatial puzzles. Notably, Castle Master was one of the first games to let you choose to play as either a prince or a princess, offering a different experience depending on your choice. Your mission: rescue your twin, imprisoned within the eerie depths of Castle Eternity by the evil Magister. This sprawling, foreboding castle is filled with traps, monsters, and puzzles blocking your path. Gather items, unlock doors, and solve complex riddles as you navigate the labyrinthine halls and confront the dark forces within. This modern reimplementation showcases enhanced graphics using OpenGL, with initial support for the DOS and ZX Spectrum releases. If you’re eager to embark on this dark journey, a playable demo is available to test your tenacity. To participate in the testing, ensure you have a daily development build. We encourage all players to submit feedback and bug reports through our issue tracker. Will you brave the creepy corridors of Castle Eternity and free your sibling, or will you fall victim to the Magister’s curse and join his army of enslaved spirits? The adventure awaits! >

entry.title: Apex Legends is revisiting the past, but it should be prouder of its present
entry.summary: Nostalgia, when you think about it, is bollocks. There has never been a better time than right this second – averaged out, and despite repeated attempts to the contrary, humanity has never been healthier, freer, or more enlightened by knowledge. It’s true of games too. For every by-committee platter of passionless map markers, there are thousands of more personal, more creative, more interesting works, all adding to the decades' worth of great stuff we can still play today. What isn’t bollocks is the emotional pull that nostalgia, for all its lack of cold, hard reason, still manages to wield inside our warm, squishy brains. Hence, the centrepiece of Apex Legends’ Season 23 update is a mode that recreates the battle royale FPS as it was back in 2019, defaulting back to the original map and weapon arsenal while cutting the 26-strong legend roster to the earliest ten. It’s a Fortnite-style rolling back of the clock, and a passably enjoyable one, but also a reminder that the good old days weren’t always that good. Read more

entry.title: I don't need to remind you that this investigation is strictly unofficial
entry.summary: We are excited to announce that Rise of the Dragon is now ready for public testing. This is the first of a small number of games built using the DGDS (Dynamix Game Development System) engine. The Dynamix name may be familiar – bought by Sierra in 1990, the Dynamix brand continued and became well known for action and puzzle games like The Incredible Machine, A10 Tank Killer, and Red Baron. They also made a few adventures using the custom DGDS engine. Rise of the Dragon is set in Los Angeles in a dark version of the future, circa 2053. You play as Blade Hunter, a private investigator and retired police officer. After a designer drug kills the mayor's rebellious daughter, Chandra, Hunter is hired to find the people responsible for releasing the drug on the streets. What Blade ultimately finds is much more than he expected. Rise of the Dragon combines classic point-and-click adventure style with platforming arcade sequences, giving a unique gameplay combination. You’ll need the latest daily build of ScummVM and files from the DOS version of the game, which you can buy at GOG (check our wiki for the required data files). Please file any issues you notice on our bug tracker. >

entry.summary: Méně erudovaný divák si může říkat, že jde o vydařenou, profesionálně natočenou, nepřístupnou sexy komedii, která je místy (hlavně ke konci) dost divná a nějak skřípe. Více erudovaný divák si může říkat, že to je odvážná hra s žánry a možná dokonce i nastavování zrcadel něčemu. Každopádně je to originální zážitek, který skoro nenudí a vypadá až překvapivě výpravně (vzhledem k omezenému rozpočtu). (Ilča 100 %)
